respStmt.resp: Transcribed from images of original letters
respStmt.name: Sarah Tew
Giuliano Sidro
Millie You
Maddie Qualls

publicationStmt.distributor: The Center for the Tebtunis Papyri, The University of California, Berkeley
publicationStmt.authority: The Board of Trinity College Dublin, The University of Dublin

availability.p: Available for academic research purposes only.

objectDesc.p: Handwritten letter of 4 pages on one folded sheet with writing on front and back. The sheet of paper appears to have been folded both ways because of a crease that divides the handwritten text and because the printed letterhead transfered onto the bottom half of the first page.
Catalog number '92' written in pencil. Previous number "100" erased and overwritten with "92".
Printed letterhead in red ink at top reads:

recordHist.p: Images taken from Trinity College, Dublin: Page 1Pages 2-3Page 4

projectDesc.p: This document was created as part of the History of Papyrology project [https://histpap.info/] by Sarah Tew, Giuliano Sidro, Maddie Qualls, and Millie You. The project is in affiliation the Center for Tebtunis Papyri at the University of California, Berkeley.

editorialDecl.p: Text has been transcribed diplomatically without corrections, normalization, or standardization.

punctuation.p: All punction marks have been retained nd represented using the appropriate Unicode code character except for apostrophes and ampersands which have been escaped using ' and &, respectively.

segmentation.p: The text has been segmented into lines according to line breaks in the original text automatically by Transkribus and line groupings based on groups identified automatically or manually declared by Sarah Tew in Transkribus. Page breaks have been manually edited by Sarah Tew, Giuliano Sidro, Maddie Qualls, and Millie You after export from Transkribus.

handNotes.handNote: Written in black ink by B.P. Grenfell.

revisionDesc.change: Manually added TEI header to Transkribus tei.xml exported file.

body.ab:
My dear Smyly,
By all means use
the double dates in the Tebtunis
cartonnáge. Call them Tebt. unpublished.
I have written to Bernard to ask
him to change the date to the of my
lectures to the week following
the Fellowship exam, if possible. I
am in his hands. I should be
delighted to stay for 6 days at

Dublin if I could spare the time,
but doubt if I can remain more than 3.
The Hibeh vol. has to
be out by December and it will
be a horrid rush to get it
finished — especially as the
papyri are very hard to read and
for various reasons we have not
yet made much progress. Besides
3 Homers all differing largely
from the received text there is a long

piece of Aristotle's treatise on
Rhetoric addressed to Alexander,
which seems to have a good many
variants but requires a lot of
cleaning before it can be deciphered
There will be after all some
double dates in the documents,
which we have hardly tackled yet
The calendar fits together tolerably
well and outght to be interesting.
I am sorry the Tebtunis cartonnage
is turning out so badly. It is
curious what bad luck we have had

in that line.
I have been entering some of the corrections
in my copy of PP.I & II and note
the following misprints in Part III
p. 53 no xxv = m.II. xxxvii (c)
p. 52. no. xxiv. Isnt συγγραφή
in (c) l. 11 not 10?
In xiv.21. supply τῆς Ἡρακλείδου
μερίδος with Ἀλαβανθίδος.

With renewed thanks for the proofs,
Yours ever
B.P.Grenfell

P.S. You might send the rest of the index
when printed.
